coredata.dc:title: CO cage recombination in hemoglobin Picosecond photolysis and nanosecond observation
coredata.dc:creator: Pin, S.
Valat, P.
Tourbez, H.
Alpert, B.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Carboxy hemoglobin in aqueous solution was photodissociated by laser pulses of 30 ps at 532 nm. Kinetic studies show that only upon complete photodissociation can the pure CO geminate binding process be revealed. The protein region of the iron cage, where the geminate ligand diffuses before reaching the heme, is smaller than a single subunit and larger than the heme pocket.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 128, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 11 July 1986 CO CAGE RECOMBINATION IN HEMOGLOBIN. PICOSECOND PHOTOLYSIS AND NANOSECOND OBSERVATION S. PIN, P. VALAT, H. TOURBEZ and B. ALPERT Laboratoire de Biologie Physico-Chimique, Unwersite de Pans VII, Tour 42-43, 2, Place Jussieu, 75251 Paris, France and Insfitut Curie, 91405 Orsay, France Received 19 March 1986; in final form 3 April 1986 Carboxy hemoglobin in aqueous solution was photodissociated by laser pulses of 30 ps at 532 nm. Kinetic studies show that only upon complete photodissociation can the pure CO geminate binding process be revealed. The protein region of the iron cage, where the geminate ligand diffuses before reaching the heme, is smaller than a single subunit and larger than the heme pocket. 1. Introduction Since the original observation of geminate iron ligand binding in hemoglobin [1], the possible effect of photolysis yield on the kinetics of CO recombina- tion has never been considered. In this paper, we re- port a room-temperature study which shows that the pure nanosecond geminate recombination is observed only upon complete photodissociation. At low pho- tolysis levels, an important fraction of CO molecules imprisoned inside the apoprotein comes into compe- tition with the geminate association. A distinction between these two mechanisms is possible from the kinetic character of the iron ligand reaction. Ligand detachment produces an electronic desta- bilization of the heme which lasts 450 ps [2]. Be- cause CO geminate recombination depends strongly upon the duration of the excitation pulse [I], CO recombination was studied in the nanosecond time range after picosecond photodissociation in order to disturb as little as possible the geminate religation process. The rebinding kinetics so far published [3,4] as- sumed implicitly that the ligand diffuses in the heme pocket. However, no studies have been carried out to determine the real size of the protein domain where the displacements of the geminate ligand are localized. In order to obtain the first experimental data on the size of the geminate recombination domain, indica- tors (such as inositol hexaphosphate and protons) bound to the protein region near and far from the heme pocket [5,6] were used for this study. 2. Experimental Human hemoglobin (Hb) was prepared according to the procedure ofPerutz [7]. Stripped hemoglobin was obtained by passing fresh hemoglobin solution through an (AG 501 Biorad) resin [8]. This stock was diluted in the buffer solution to give the desired concentration (3 X 10~5 M in heme). Inositol hexa- phosphate (IHP) was purchased as the sodium salt of phytic acid (Sigma Chemical Co., type V, lot No. 5756) dissolved in the buffer solution when required in tenfold molar to tetramer Hb excess, and then the pH was adjusted to 7 or 9. Buffer concentration was 2 X 10-3 M. Oxygen in the solution was removed under vacu- um, and CO gas equilibration was performed directly in the tonometer containing the deoxyhemoglobin form. Then the fraction of total CO ligation was mea- sured on the Cary 219 spectrophotometer with a thermostatted sample compartment. CO dissociation experiments have been performed under different conditions ofpH (7 and 9), with and without IHP 0 009-2614/86/S 03.50 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. (North-Holland Physics Publishing Division) 79 Volume 128, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 11 July 1986 and temperature (7 35 C). To be sure that the nano- second recombination involves principally the CO molecule which returns to its original binding site (and not some free CO molecules imprisoned inside the apoprotein or dissolved in the aqueous solvent) geminate experiments were performed at low CO concentration and 95% of full CO association. Photodissociation of HbCO was produced by a 30 ps pulse of the second harmonic (532 nm) from a YAG Quantel laser. Pulse energies varied from 0.4 to 1 mJ/mm2. The hemoglobin solutions exposed to the laser were contained in rectangular cells (2X10 mm) with the 10 mm side facing the laser beam. Transient light transmission changes of the irradiated sample were measured at the Soret absorption band (419 and 438 nm) of the protein across the 2 mm cell width using a flash-lamp-mohochromator photo- multiplier apparatus with a time resolution of 5 ns. The instrumentation utilized was modified from ar- rangements previously described [1,2]. The photo- dissociating and interrogating beams overlapped in the sample volume. The intensity of the flash lamp was adjusted sufficiently low to avoid an appreciable photodissociation and yet high enough to permit the measurement of the variation in absorbance (500 ns after the excitation pulse) with an accuracy of 0.01 OD for an optical density of 1.2 at 419 nm. The data shown are the average of 15 shots. 3. Results The time reaction laws were monitored at the iso- bestic points (419 and 438 nm) for the slower optical information on proton structural adjustments as was shown in previous time-resolved absorption studies [1,9]. The extent of HbCO dissociation just after the picosecond laser excitation was monitored as a function of laser energy. At low laser energy, the am- plitude of the variation was directly proportional to the energy. At high intensities, the OD change (due to CO liberation) was found to reach a limiting value independent of the laser energy. This limiting OD change seems to indicate that only 75 80% of the starting material was photolysed. However, our ex- perimental time resolution (5 ns) of the kinetic spec- trophotometer was not sufficient to record the rapid- ly changing light intensity at the beginning of the li- gand recombination without distortion, and the above value therefore represents a lower limit. The light sat- uration effect demonstrates that the HbCO present in the irradiated volume was completely dissociated at high laser energies. We must note, here, that with shorter pulse widths (10 ps) Chernoffet al. [10] re- port the same apparent initial photodissociation of HbCO and see less than 10% CO recombination in the first 1.2 ns after the photolysis pulse. Our obser- vation is consistent with this work. Thus, at the high- est laser energies, we have fitted the experimental curve, excluding the experimental original OD varia- tion. At the time t = 0 (time of laser picosecond ex- citation) we have chosen the real optical amplitude for 100% of HbCO dissociated complex. At low laser energies the experimental OD variations were too small to yield accurate corrected values. We have con- sidered that the experimental zero-time amplitude gave, approximately, the original photolysis level. With these assumptions, the reaction time-course of the CO recombination for the low levels of photol- ysis (less than %50%) was best represented by a sum of two exponentials in accord with previous studies [9,11,12]. However, the proportion of the compo- nents and the rate constants vary with the photolysis level. At complete photodissociation, the combination was found to obey the relation: C,-C,=^exp[-(r/r)1/2], where Cy is the concentration of deligated hemoglobin at time t after laser excitation and C , that at the end of the geminate recombination. Very satisfactory fits were obtained in all cases. The quality of the fits is illustrated by the smooth curve superimposed on the experimental recombination signal (fig. 1). The discrepancy between the reaction time-courses at complete and low level of photolysis neatly sepa- rates the contribution of pure geminate recombination (heme ligand bond formation) and the back reaction from some free CO molecules. To minimize the com- peting reaction of CO molecules trapped inside the protein medium with the CO molecule which returns to its original iron binding site (geminate pair recom- bination process), it was necessary to work at almost complete photodissociation and at very low ligand concentration. Indeed, at total photodissociation using 80 Volume 128, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 11 July 1986 AD(, 0.5 Table 1 Temperature dependence (at pH 7) on the percentage of heme-CO recombined at the end of geminate binding (500 ns after the photolytic pulse). Accuracy measurements: 0.02 Temperature ( C) Heme-recombined fraction < 01 c; 0 s02 ?,1 100 300 350ns 250 200 TIME Fig. 1. Experimental and smooth kinetic curves of CO gemi- nate recombination in human hemoglobin produced by 30 ps Hash photolysis. Experiment was performed at 15 C. Op- tical measurements were done at 419 nm and ADsoo repre- sents the absorbance change 500 ns after the photolysis pulse. This time corresponds at the end of CO geminate binding. A complete CO dissociation during the excitation time gives the theoretical absorbance change of A >o- 3 X 10-5 M of hemoglobin and 100 pM of CO, the ra- tio gives 2 free CO molecules which compete with one gemmate CO molecule. This ratio reaches 6 when the level of the photolysis decreases to 40%. It increases to 20 when the partial photolysis is only 10%. From this remark and previous work [13,14], we confirm that at room temperature nanosecond gemmate re- combination in hemoglobin follows a f1/2 kinetics as expected for diffusion processes [10,13 15]. Therefore, to obtain the recombination involving principally the real geminate pair recombination pro- cess, all data reported in the following were taken under light saturation conditions. Next the temperature dependence of the CO gemi- nate recombination was investigated. Indeed, the gem- inate CO binding to hemoglobin is simultaneously controlled by the interaction of the ligand with the 0.77 0.70 0.62 0.55 7 15 25 35 iron and the movement of the ligand through the protein. Table 1 shows the temperature dependence of the percentage of heme CO recombined at the end of geminate ligand rebinding. Contrary to the kinetics of chemical iron ligand binding, increasing temperature decreases the geminate ligand binding yield. This contrast shows that CO geminate recom- bination in hemoglobin is governed more by diffu- sion inside the bulk protein than by the chemical reactivity of the iron. At different pH values, in the presence as in ab- sence of IHP, the fractions of the heme which had recombined with CO at the end of the geminate phase were also measured. Table 2 summarizes the results obtained at 20 C with and without IHP, at two pH values (7 and 9). The values are the average of 12 experiments obtained with different preparations. The data clearly indicate that only the IHP (at pH 7) perturbs the geminate recombination of the photo- dissociated HbCO, and slows down the heme CO re- combination. Table 2 Effect of IHP on heme-recombined fraction at the end of CO geminate binding (500 ns after the Hash photolysis). Experiments were performed at 20 C in bis Tris (pH 7) and Tris buffer (pH 9). Estimated accuracy 0.02 pH Heme-recombined fraction without IHP with IHP 0.65 0.65 0.50 0.65 81 \Volume 128, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 11 July 1986 4. Discussion Because the fast relaxations reported here ex- clude structural R-T change contributions (>1 JUS) [9,16,17] one can consider that in our photolysis experiment sudden removal of bound CO produces deoxyhemoglobin with the pre-existent equilibria between the different quaternary states of the pro- tein conformations. And over the nanosecond time period, hemoglobin interactions with the surround- ing medium (protons and allosteric effectors) appear quite stable and without changes. In the present study, monitored at 419 and 438 nm, the isobestic points for slower tertiary structure changes [1,9], we can neglect conformational relaxation and con- sider that all initial parameters (except the CO free molecules) were unchanged during the CO gemmate rebinding. It is known that, at the end of the geminate phase, the number ofligands which return to their original binding sites depends significantly on pulse duration [1,18,19]. Long laser pulses can rephotolyse bound CO molecules until all of the CO is removed to the aqueous buffer solution. The higher extent of recom- bination at the end of the geminate phase in the pres- ent study at 20 C ( <65%) (see table 2) compared to that in the nanosecond photolysis (^35%) [1,20] is probably due to the existence of repetitive HbCO photodissociation with the nanosecond pulses. In- deed some studies of CO recombination following picosecond excitation showed no evidence of recom-. bination in the first 700 ps after the photolysis [21,22]. From our CO kinetic data, in a 30 ps pho- tolysis experiment, any CO molecule can recombine with its original iron during the picosecond pulse. So, using photolysis laser pulses of 30 ps fwhm, and monitoring the CO recombination in the nanosecond time range, one sees the real geminate religation pro- cess of the iron-CO pairs. Undoubtedly longer pho- tolysis flashes perturb the distance between these partners, disturb the distribution ofligand molecules inside the protein [1,18,19], and modify the proba- bility of escape of CO molecules from the protein. Thus the recombination kinetics depend on the dura- tion of the excitation light and on its intensity. The effect of the photolysis time on the binding kinetics has been clearly demonstrated [1]. In con- trast, the effect of photolysis level is less clear. First described by Gibson [23] in the millisecond time range, it was totally forgotten in shorter-time photo- dissociation experiments. As suggested by the pres- ent studies on partially photodeligated Hb, the distri- bution of ligand molecules throughout the apoprotein ensemble varies widely with the extent of the photo- dissociation. And thus, the kinetic character of the reaction (which is related to the distance between the iron and the ligand) depends drastically on the population of ligand molecules which remain inside the protein. Thus it becomes obvious that for long pulse widths, high ligand concentrations or partial photolysis, two binding processes compete and the kinetics ofligand rebinding to the iron sites differ from pure cage re- combination (kinetics in exp( f1^)) and from sim- ple non-geminate association (kinetics in exp(-f)). This competition is the reason why contradictory data are reported in the literature [1,9,11 13,24]. Nanosecond photodissociation of HbCO has shown that the escape rate of CO from the protein increases with the temperature [12,20,25,26]. These rates should also depend on the irradiation conditions. Thus, it is important to determine the true geminate rates and compare the different recombination yields under different pulsed excitation conditions. Since picosecond laser pulses can be considered as delta functions, the real fractional CO recombination at different temperatures can be calculated (table 1). It can be seen that a pulse width of a few nanoseconds [20,26] can drastically perturb the effect of temper- ature on the geminate recombination. Results shown in table 2 show that the IHP effec- tor greatly modifies the geminate recombination. As demonstrated by XANES spectroscopy [27], the elec- tronic state of the heme iron is totally independent of the hemoglobin heterotropic effectors, thus the modifications in the iron-CO pairs must be essential- ly dependent upon the diffusion capacity of the ligand inside the globin. The protein moiety is a strongly in- homogeneous medium, and the ligand displacements into this matrix appear very restricted. Thus the dif- ference in binding affinity of the hemoglobin, with and without the effectors, could be attributed to some steric change of the protein interior [12,28,29]. How- ever, protein structure is not static. X-ray models of proteins are the space average of a large number of structures which are interconverting by thermal mo- 82 Volume 128, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 11 July 1986 tion. The fluctuations in the polypeptide chain con- formation would be sufficient to create a high degree of randomness to the ligand movements on the 100 ns timescale. AUosteric effectors could alter the mo- lecular motions of the apoprotein, and in this way change the rates of geminate ligand binding. However pH changes, which shift the S-shape ligandation curve (Bohr effect) [30], do not affect the CO geminate re- ligation. These heterotropic interactions which in- fluence the ligand binding equilibria apparently act too far from the heme [6] to perturb the CO geminate recombination. Indeed in the geminate regime, the iron and ligand are coupled in a spatial cage with di- mensions smaller than those of the apoprotein. CO geminate recombination (observed in the room-tem- perature range) must reflect the continuous rearrange- ments of the amino-acid residues relatively close to the heme. In addition, it is known that IHP binding to hemoglobin creates some perturbations in the ter- tiary structure of the (3 chains which extend to the heme region [5]. These considerations indicate that the size of the iron CO cage is much smaller than the volume of a hemoglobin subunit, restricted to a small sphere centered on the heme iron, and larger than the heme pocket, itself. Thus ligand diffusion inside the hemoglobin and the rate of escape of CO from this protein should depend principally on inter- nal flexibility of this cage region. Raising tempera- ture increases the protein fluctuations and favors the ligand random diffusion process, thus resulting in a smaller fraction of CO geminate molecules which rebind the iron. It thus appears that the CO gemmate molecules are never restricted to displacement inside the heme cavity alone, but enter the globin matrix around this heme cavity. References [1] B. Alpert, S. El Mohsni, L. Lindqvist and F. Tfibel, Chem.Phys. Letters 64 (1979) 11. [2] P. Valat, H. Tourbez and B. Alpert, Laser Chem. 1 (1982)45. [3] R.H. Austin, K.W. Beeson, L. Eisenstein, H. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Carboxy hemoglobin in aqueous solution was photodissociated by laser pulses of 30 ps at 532 nm. Kinetic studies show that only upon complete photodissociation can the pure CO geminate binding process be revealed. The protein region of the iron cage, where the geminate ligand diffuses before reaching the heme, is smaller than a single subunit and larger than the heme pocket.

sb:title.sb:maintitle: Interaction between iron and protein in oxygen and electron transport
